2.title: Eliezer Yudkowsky
2.clickbait: Cofounder, with Nick Bostrom, of the field of value alignment theory.

178.title: Arbital "tag" relationship
178.clickbait: Tags are a way to connect pages that share a common topic.

370.editSummary: reflecting the fact that we only have one type of mark now.
370.title: Arbital mark
370.clickbait: What is a mark on Arbital? When is it created? Why is it important?

597.title: Arbital page clickbait
597.clickbait: The text you are reading right now is clickbait.

10h.title: Paperclip maximizer
10h.clickbait: This agent will not stop until the entire universe is filled with paperclips.

17b.title: Arbital lens
17b.clickbait: A lens is a page that presents another page's content from a different angle.

18r.title: Expected utility agent
18r.clickbait: If you're not some kind of expected utility agent, you're going in circles.

1ln.editSummary: alias. note to self: come back and explain new requisites system.
1ln.title: Arbital requisites
1ln.clickbait: To understand a thing you often need to understand some other things.

1lw.title: Mathematics
1lw.clickbait: Mathematics is the study of numbers and other ideal objects that can be described by axioms.

1rt.title: Arbital path
1rt.clickbait: Arbital path is a linear sequence of pages tailored specifically to teach a given concept to a user.

2c.title: Advanced agent properties
2c.clickbait: How smart does a machine intelligence need to be, for its niceness to become an issue?  "Advanced" is a broad term to cover cognitive abilities such that we'd need to start considering AI alignment.

2mx.title: Open subproblems in aligning a Task-based AGI
2mx.clickbait: Open research problems, especially ones we can model today, in building an AGI that can "paint all cars pink" without turning its future light cone into pink-painted cars.

2pf.title: Low impact
2pf.clickbait: The open problem of having an AI carry out tasks in ways that cause minimum side effects and change as little of the rest of the universe as possible.

2r8.title: Mild optimization
2r8.clickbait: An AGI which, if you ask it to paint one car pink, just paints one car pink and doesn't tile the universe with pink-painted cars, because it's not trying *that* hard to max out its car-painting score.

2v.title: AI alignment
2v.clickbait: The great civilizational problem of creating artificially intelligent computer systems such that running them is a good idea.

2xd.title: Shutdown problem
2xd.clickbait: How to build an AGI that lets you shut it down, despite the obvious fact that this will interfere with whatever the AGI's goals are.

36y.title: Goal-concept identification
36y.clickbait: Figuring out how to say "strawberry" to an AI that you want to bring you strawberries (and not fake plastic strawberries, either).

3d.title: Arbital
3d.clickbait: Arbital is the place for crowdsourced, intuitive math explanations.

3hs.title: Author's guide to Arbital
3hs.clickbait: How to write intuitive, flexible content on Arbital.

3n.title: Arbital "parent" relationship
3n.clickbait: Parent-child relationship between pages implies a strong, inseparable connection.

42g.title: Artificial General Intelligence
42g.clickbait: An AI which has the same kind of "significantly more general" intelligence that humans have compared to chimpanzees; it can learn new domains, like we can.

4l.title: Safe impact measure
4l.clickbait: What can we measure to make sure an agent is acting in a safe manner?

4mn.title: Task (AI goal)
4mn.clickbait: When building the first AGIs, it may be wiser to assign them only goals that are bounded in space and time, and can be satisfied by bounded efforts.
4mn.text:
[summary:  A "Task" is an [2c AI] goal that only covers a bounded amount of space and time, and can be satisfied by a limited amount of effort.

An example might be "fill this cauldron with water before 1pm"; but even there, we have to be careful.  "Maximize the probability that this cauldron contains water at 1pm" would imply unlimited effort, since slightly higher probabilities could be obtained by adding more and more effort.

"Carry out some policy such that there's at least a 95% chance that the cauldron is at least 90% full of water by 1pm" would be more definitely a Task, since a limited effort is definitely enough to do that, and then it can't be done any more by expending more effort.

See also [2pf], [2r8] and [6w].]

A "Task" is a goal, intended for use in an [2v aligned] [2c advanced] AI, that the AI can satisfy by optimizing a bounded part of space, for a limited time, with a limited amount of effort.

E.g., "make as many [10h paperclips] as possible" is definitely not a Task, since it counts every paperclip anywhere in space and future time.  Creating more and more paperclips, using more and more effort, is then more and more preferable up to the maximum exertable effort.

For a more subtle example of non-Taskness, consider Disney's "sorcerer's apprentice" scenario:  Mickey Mouse commands a broomstick to fill a cauldron, and the broomstick empties more and more water into the cauldron until the workshop is flooded.  (Mickey then tries to destroy the broomstick.  But since the broomstick has no [2xd designed-in reflectively stable shutdown button], the broomstick repairs itself and begins constructing subagents that go on pouring more water into the cauldron.)

Since the Disney cartoon is a musical, we don't know if the broomstick was given a time bound on its job.  Let us suppose that Mickey tells the broomstick to do its job sometime before 1pm.

Then we might imagine that the broomstick is a subjective [18r expected utility] maximizer with a utility function $U_{cauldron}$ over outcomes $o$:

$$U_{cauldron}(o):  \begin{cases}
1 & \text{if in $o$ the cauldron is $\geq 90\%$ full of water at 1pm} \\
0 & \text{otherwise}
\end{cases}$$

This *looks* at first glance like it ought to be a Task:

- The cauldron is bounded in space.
- The goal only concerns events that happen before a certain time.
- The highest utility that can be achieved is $1,$ which is reached as soon as the cauldron is $\geq 90\%$ full of water, which seems achievable using a limited amount of effort.

The last property in particular makes $U_{cauldron}$ a "satisficing utility function", one where an outcome is either satisfactory or not-satisfactory, and it is not possible to do any better than "satisfactory".

However, the broomstick is still maximizing *expected* utility.  Assume the broomstick reasons with [42g reasonable generality], using some reasonably [4mr universal prior].  Then the *subjective probability* of the cauldron being full, when it *looks* full to the broomstick, [4mq will not be] *exactly* $1.$  Perhaps (the broomstick-agent reasons) the broomstick's cameras are malfunctioning, or its RAM has malfunctioned producing an inaccurate memory.

Then the broomstick reasons that it can further increase the probability of the cauldron being full - however slight the increase in probability - by going ahead and dumping in another bucket of water.

To put it another way, [4mq Cromwell's Rule] implies that the subjective probability of the bucket being full never reaches exactly $1$.  Then there can be an infinite series of increasingly preferred, increasingly more effortful policies $\pi_1, \pi_2, \pi_3 \ldots$ with

$$\mathbb E [ U_{cauldron} | \pi_1] = 0.99\\
\mathbb E [ U_{cauldron} | \pi_2] = 0.999 \\
\mathbb E [ U_{cauldron} | \pi_3] = 0.999002 \\
\ldots$$

In that case the broomstick can always do better in expected utility (however slightly) by exerting even more effort, up to the maximum effort it can exert.  Hence the flooded workshop.

If on the other hand the broomstick is an *expected utility satisficer*, i.e., a policy is "acceptable" if it has $\mathbb E [ U_{cauldron} | \pi ] \geq 0.95,$ then this is now finally a Task (we think).  The broomstick can find some policy that's reasonably sure of filling up the cauldron, execute it, and then do no more.

As described, this broomstick doesn't yet have any [4l impact penalty], or features for [2r8 mild optimization].  So the broomstick could *also* get $\geq 0.90$ expected utility by flooding the whole workshop; we haven't yet [2r8 forbidden excess efforts].  Similarly, the broomstick could also go on to destroy the world after 1pm - we haven't forbidden excess [4l impact] later.

But the underlying rule of "Execute a policy that fills the cauldron at least 90% full with at least 95% probability" does appear to be a Task, so far as we know.  It seems at least *possible* for an otherwise well-designed agent to execute this goal as well as possible, by acting in bounded space, over a bounded time, with a limited amount of effort.  There does not appear to be a sequence of policies the agent would evaluate as better fulfilling its decision criterion, which use successively more and more effort.

The "taskiness" of this goal, even assuming it was correctly [36y identified], wouldn't by itself make the broomstick a safe [6w Task AGI].  But it would be a start, and make further safety features more feasible/useful.

See also [2r8] as an [2mx open problem in AGI alignment].

4mq.title: Empirical probabilities are not exactly 0 or 1
4mq.clickbait: "Cromwell's Rule" says that probabilities of exactly 0 or 1 should never be applied to empirical propositions - there's always some probability, however tiny, of being mistaken.

4mr.title: Universal prior
4mr.clickbait: A "universal prior" is a probability distribution containing *all* the hypotheses, for some reasonable meaning of "all".  E.g., "every possible computer program that computes probabilities".

6w.title: Task-directed AGI
6w.clickbait: An advanced AI that's meant to pursue a series of limited-scope goals given it by the user.  In Bostrom's terminology, a Genie.
